{{About|the play by Jean Giradoux|other uses|Electra (disambiguation)}}
{{Infobox play | name = [[Electra]] | image = Jadwiga Jankowska-Cieślak i Andrzej Szczepkowski, Elektra, Warszawa (1973).JPG | image_size = 280px | caption = [[Jadwiga Jankowska-Cieślak]] as Electra in Warsaw, 1973 | writer = [[Jean Giraudoux]] | characters = [[Agamemnon]], [[Iphigenia]], [[Clytemnestra]], [[Aegisthus]], [[Orestes]], [[Electra]] | chorus = [[Erinyes|The Eumenides]] | setting = Mythological ancient Greece | premiere = 13 May 1937 | place = [[Théâtre de l'Athénée]] in [[Paris]] | orig_lang = French | subject = Electra and her brother Orestes plot revenge against their mother Clytemnestra and stepfather Aegisthus for the murder of their father, Agamemnon | genre = [[Tragedy]] }} ''''' Electra ''''' (French title: ''Électre'') is a two-act play written in 1937 by French dramatist [[Jean Giraudoux]]. It was the first Giraudoux play to employ the staging of [[Louis Jouvet]]. Based on the classic myth of antiquity, ''Electra'' has a surprisingly tragic force, without losing the spirit and sparkling humor that made Jean Giraudoux one of the most important playwrights of the mid twentieth century.
==Original productions== ''Électre'' was translated into English as ''Electra'' in 1955 by Winifred Smith,<ref>Bentley, Eric, ''The Modern Theatre, Volume 1, 5 Plays, edited by Eric Bentley'', Anchor, January, 1955, ASIN B00150AB5S</ref> and again in 1964 by Phyllis La Farge and Peter H. Judd.<ref>Giraudoux, Jean (1964), '' Three Plays, vol 2'', Translated by Phyllis La Farge and Peter H. Judd, Hill and Wang, New York</ref><ref>Cohen, Robert (1968), ''Jean Giraudoux; Three Faces of Destiny'', p. 157, University of Chicago Press, Chicago. {{ISBN|0-226-11248-9}}</ref>
''Électre'' was first performed on 13 May 1937<ref>Grossvogel, David I. (1958), '' 20th Century French Drama'', p. 341, Columbia University Press, New York.</ref> in Paris at the [[Théâtre de l'Athénée]] in a production by [[Louis Jouvet]].<ref>Inskip, Donald, (1958), '' Jean Giraudoux, The Making of a Dramatist'', p. 182, Oxford University Press, New York.</ref>
==Plot summary== [[Agamemnon]], The King of Argos, had sacrificed his daughter [[Iphigenia]] to the gods. In revenge, his wife, [[Clytemnestra]], assisted by her lover, Aegisthus, killed him on his return from the [[Trojan War]]. [[Orestes]], the son was banished, but the second daughter Electra was allowed to remain: "She does nothing, says nothing. But she is there". As the play opens, Aegisthus wants to marry her to the palace gardener in order to deflect towards "the house of Théocathoclès anything that might cast an unfortunate light on the [[Atreus|house of Atreus]]."
Electra, with the assistance of her easily dominated brother Orestes, who has returned from banishment, relentlessly seeks the murderer of her father, while feeling an implacable hatred for her mother. Eventually Electra and Orestes themselves are destroyed by the curse that follows the house of Atreus.
Giraudoux's play is a rewriting of the myth, taken from an epic passage in [[Homer]]'s [[Odyssey]]. It had previously been rendered in tragedies by [[Aeschylus]], [[Sophocles]], and [[Euripides]] in the 5th century BC.
With many anachronistic changes, including the role of the [[bourgeois]] couple as a burlesque reflection of the tragic couple, Elektra is another example of the timelessness of the tragedy. Written in 1937, it would in effect be a "bourgeois tragedy", according to Jean Giraudoux himself.
== The quest for the truth == This is the main theme of the play. Electra comes from the Greek ''Elektra'' which means "light". Electra is there to shed light on the events, to illuminate the truth. Thanks to her presence, many characters will reveal "their" truth, such as Agathe in Act II, 6. In addition, Electra and Aegisthus declare themselves throughout the play.
The character of the beggar (at once god, beggar and director) helps restore the truth. It is he who explains how the story unfolds, who recounts the murder of Agamemnon, and also that of Aegisthus and Clytemnestra.
The last scene shows Electra, in restoring the truth, cursed and dispossessed, decimating the city. The splendor of this truth was too violent. The last line, "It has a beautiful name, Narses, it is called the dawn" ends the play on a delicious note of ambiguity.
== Characters ==
=== Characters ===
* [[Electra]]. As mentioned previously, it is really the central character. Daughter of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra, she hates her mother who killed her father with the help of her lover Aegisthus, who is now Regent to the throne. She awaits the arrival of Orestes in revenge. * [[Orestes]]. Electra's brother, he was very young exile and returned to his family by appearing as a mere alien. * [[Clytemnestra]]. Mother of Electra and Orestes, Agamemnon's widow and lover of Aegisthus, queen of Argos. * [[Aegisthus]]. Regent, he holds the power in the city of Argos. The play begins on the consequences of his ideas: Electra married the gardener, and thus deter the Gods of their views on the line of Atreus. * The Chairman. Second President of the court, he cares for his peace and opposes Aegisthus. * Agatha. President's wife, she is young and pretty, and decides to deceive her husband. * The gardener. Future husband of Electra, he looks after the garden of the palace. He belongs to the same family as the President. * The [[Erinyes|Eumenides]]. Girls at the beginning of the play, they grow several years in a few hours. They are related to the gods and justice. * The Beggar. Enigmatic character: ((Citation | Never has there been a beggar as perfect as a beggar, as rumor has it that this must be a God)). * Narses. Friend of the Beggar.
===Other characters===
* A young man * A master * The Butlers * A groomsman * Beggars
== Cast ==
* [[Renee Devillers]]: ''[[Electra]]'' * [[Gabrielle Dorziat]]: ''[[Clytemnestra]]'' * [[Madeleine Ozeray]]: '' ''Agatha'' * [[Raymone]]: ''Women Narses'' * [[Martha Herlin]]: ''Fury'' * [[Monique Mélinand]]: ''Fury'' * [[Pezzani Denise]]: ''Fury'' * [[Vera Perez]]: '' ''Little Fury'' * [[Nicole Fitted Berny]]: '' ''Little Fury'' * [[Clairette Fournier]]: '' ''Little Fury'' * [[Louis Jouvet]]: ''The Beggar'' * [[Pierre Renoir]]: ''[[Aegisthus]]'' * [[Romain Bouquet]]: ''President'' * [[Paul Cambo]]: ''[[Orestes]]'' * [[Alfred Adam]]: ''The Gardener'' * [[John Deninx]]: ''the young man'' * [[Robert Bogar]]: ''Captain'' * [[Maurice Castel]]: ''best man'' * [[Julien Barrot]]: ''butler'' * [[René Belloc]]: ''butler'' * [[Andre Moreau]]: ''beggar''
==References== <references/>
== External links == * {{iobdb title|4470| Electra}} * [http://www.bacdefrancais.net/electre.php literary Comments: major scenes in the play]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = | name = Frank Garcia | birth_name = Frank Garcia | nationality = American | known_for = [[sleight of hand]], [[card magic]], [[card sharp]] | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1927|05|08}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan]], New York, US | occupation = [[Illusionist|Magician]], performer, teacher, author | spouse = Betty Lou Field-Garcia (Moss) | death_date = {{Dda|1993|07|15|1927|05|08}} | children = 1 | height = {{convert|6|ft|2|in}} }} '''Frank Garcia''' (May 8, 1927 – July 15, 1993) was a [[Illusionist|magician]] and professional [[gambling|gambler]]. He was known as "The Man With The Million Dollar Hands." His specialty was [[gambling]] scams and [[cheating]].
The son of [[Spanish people|Spanish]] [[immigrants]], he decided to become a magician after seeing a performance of [[David (Fu Manchu) Bamberg|David "Fu Manchu" Bamberg]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.magicnook.com/forum/bioFG.htm |title=Biographies Page F-G}}</ref>
As "The Gambling Investigator" he demonstrated and exposed cheating methods at [[trade shows]] and to [[Law enforcement agency|law enforcement]] organizations throughout the United States and on [[television]] shows. Frank Garcia wrote and lectured about the subject throughout his life.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cardcheaters.com/garcia-frank.htm |title=Frank Garcia - CardCheater.com}}</ref>
Garcia made "close-up" work his domain. His repertory of [[card manipulation]]s, sponge-ball magic, cups and balls, and sleight-of-hand was highly regarded by his peers.<ref name="obit">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/07/20/obituaries/frank-garcia-a-master-magician-who-aided-the-police-dies-at-66.html |title=A Master Magician Who Aided the Police | work=The New York Times | first=Wolfgang | last=Saxon | date=July 20, 1993 | accessdate=May 2, 2010}}</ref>
Frank was a frequent guest on TV talk shows including The Dick Cavett Show, and David Suskind, sometimes performing magic and sometimes revealing the scams of crooked gamblers such as three card monte players on the streets of New York.
== Published works == Garcia wrote 12 books in his life. The books were written about [[card shark|card cheating]], gambling, and most especially close-up card magic. Some of his magic books are considered collectors items. His most famous books were: * Encyclopedia of Sponge Ball Magic (1976) * Million Dollar Card Secrets (1972) * Super Subtle Card Miracles (1973) * Exclusive Card Secrets (1980) * Exclusive Card Miracles (1980) * The Close Up Card Magic of Frank Garcia, Part I (1982) * The Close Up Card Magic of Frank Garcia, Part II (1982) * Marked Cards And Loaded Dice (1962) which was later released as How To Detect Crooked Gambling (1977) * All In A Nutshell (1974) * Don't Bet On It ! (1978) * Magic With Cards (1974) (co-authored with George Schindler) * Amedeo's Continental Magic (co-authored with George Schindler)
==Death== Frank died at age 66 on July 15, 1993 from a stroke in his apartment right before he was going to move in with his wife for the first time. His wife, Betty Moss, now lives alone with her son.<ref name="obit"/>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://geniimagazine.com/wiki/index.php/Frank_Garcia Frank Garcia MagicPedia entry] *[http://www.dailymotion.com/video/k1eCcwA1sOXjhmJyyR Frank Garcia performing the Three Shell game] *[http://www.magictricks.com/bios/whoswho-s.htm Who's who in magic history]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=December 2012}}
'''French impressionist cinema''' ('''first avant-garde''' or '''narrative avant-garde''') refers to a group of French films and filmmakers of the 1920s.
Film scholars have had much difficulty in defining this movement or for that matter deciding whether it should be considered a movement at all. [[David Bordwell]] has attempted to define a unified stylistic paradigm and set of tenets. <sup>1</sup> Others, namely [[Richard Abel (cultural historian)|Richard Abel]], criticize these attempts and group the films and filmmakers more loosely, based on a common goal of "exploration of the process of representation and signification in narrative film discourse." <sup>2</sup> Still others such as [[Dudley Andrew]] would struggle with awarding any credibility at all as "movement." <sup>3</sup>
== Filmmakers and films (selection) == *[[Abel Gance]] (''[[La Dixième symphonie]]'' 1918, ''[[J'accuse (1919 film)|J’Accuse]]'' 1919, ''[[La Roue]]'' 1922, and, above all, ''[[Napoléon (1927 film)|Napoléon]]'' 1927) *[[Jean Epstein]] (''[[Coeur fidèle]]'' 1923, ''Six et demi onze'' 1927, ''La Glace a Trois Face'' 1928, and ''[[The Fall of the House of Usher (1928 French film)| The Fall of the House of Usher]]'' 1928) *[[Germaine Dulac]] (''[[The Smiling Madame Beudet]]'' 1922) *[[Marcel L'Herbier]] (''El Dorado'' 1921) *[[Louis Delluc]] – (''[[La Femme de nulle part]]'' 1922) *[[Jean Renoir]] (''[[Nana (1926 film)|Nana]]'' 1926)
== Periodization ==
1. Pictorialism (beginning in 1918): made up of films that focus mainly on manipulation of the film as image, through camerawork, mise-en-scene, and optical devices.
2. Montage (beginning in 1923): at which point rhythmic and fast-paced editing became more widely used.
3. Diffusion (beginning in 1926): at which point films and filmmakers began to pursue other stylistic and formal modes.
== Stylistic paradigm ==
Based on David Bordwell’s family resemblance model: <sup>4</sup>
'''I. Camerawork'''
A. Camera distance: close-up (as synecdoche, symbol or subjective image)
B. Camera angle (high or low)
C. Camera movement (independent of subject, for graphic effects, point of view)
'''II. Mise-en-scene'''
A. Lighting (single source, shadows indicating off-screen actions, variety of lighting situations)
B. Décor
C. Arrangement and movement of figures in space
'''III. Optical devices'''
A. As transitions
B. As magical effects
C. As emphasizing significant details
D. As pictoral decoration
E. As conveyors of abstract meanings
F. As indications of objectivity (mental images, semi-subjective images, optical subjectivity)
'''IV. Characteristic editing patterns'''
A. Temporal relations between shots (Flashback or fantasy)
B. Spatial relation between shots (synthetic, glance/object, crosscutting)
C. Rhythmic relations between shots
== Relation to/deviation from Hollywood stylistics ==
However, even Marcel L’Herbier, one of the chief filmmakers associated with the movement, admitted to an ununified theoretical stance: "None of us – Dulac, Epstein, Delluc or myself – had the same aesthetic outlook. But we had a common interest, which was the investigation of that famous cinematic specificity. On this we agreed completely." <sup>5</sup>
Richard Abel’s re-evaluation of Bordwell’s analysis sees the films as a reaction to conventional stylistic and formal paradigms, rather than Bordwell’s resemblance model. Thus Abel refers to the movement as the Narrative Avant-Garde. He views the films as a reaction to narrative paradigm found in commercial filmmaking, namely that of Hollywood, and is based on literary and generic referentiality, narration through intertitles, syntactical continuity, a rhetoric based on verbal language and literature, and a linear narrative structure <sup>6</sup>, then subverts it, varies it, deviates from it.
== Criticism ==
The movement is also often credited with the origins of film criticism and Louis Delluc is often cited as the first film critic. The movement published journals and periodicals reviewing recent films and discussing trends and ideas about cinema.
Cine-clubs were also formed by filmmakers and enthusiasts, which screened hand picked films: select American fare, German and Swedish films, but most often films made by the members of the clubs themselves.
== Theory ==
The narrative avant-garde did have a theoretical base, although its divergent articulation by different writer-filmmakers has confused the issue to a certain extent. Much of it is an extension of [[Symbolist]] [[poetics]] that posit a realm beyond matter and our immediate sense experience that art and the artist attempt to reveal and express <sup>7</sup>. Bordwell goes on to point out the massive holes in this theorization, that the true nature of reality and experience are never established. Holes aside, the narrative avant-garde explores the perception of reality, and does so through two main concepts: subjectivity and photogénie. Neither of these terms is easily explainable, if at all, but that is part of the point — for these filmmakers explored an unattainable understanding that can only be reached for. French impressionism destabilized familiar or objective ways of seeing, creating new dynamics of human perception. Using strange and imaginative effects, it altered traditional views and aimed to question the norm of the film industry at the time.
;''[[Subjectivity]]''
Through the properties noted above in Bordwell’s stylistic paradigm, filmmakers sought to portray the internal state of the character or characters and in some of the later and more complex films attempt to bring the audience into the equation as subjective participant.
;''Photogénie''
Photogénie occurs at the meeting of the profilmic (what is in front of the camera) and the mechanical and the filmmaker. It is above all a defamiliarization of the spectator with what appears on screen. It is a property that cannot be found in "reality" itself, a camera that is simply switched on does not record it, and a filmmaker cannot simply point it out. As Aitken summarizes, "…fully realized photogénie could only be manifested when its latent power was employed to express the vision of the film-maker, so that the inherent poetry of the cinema could be harnessed, and developed in a revelatory manner by the auteur" <sup>8</sup>. However, the narrative avant-garde lacked a theoretical and philosophical base upon which these notions rest and thus the concept of photogénie is always on the edge of an inexplicable mysticism that many critics cannot accept.
== Notes ==
1. Bordwell, David. ''French Impressionist Cinema''. New York: Arno Press, 1980.
2. Abel, Richard. ''French Cinema: The First Wave 1915–1929''. New Jersey: Princeton University Press, 1984.
3. Andrew, Dudley. ''Mists of Regret''. New Jersey: Princeton University Press, 1995.
4. Bordwell, Appendix B pp. 270–292.
5. Aitken, Ian. ''European Film Theory and Criticism: A Critical Introduction''. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press: 2001. p. 82.
6. Abel p. 292-294
7. Bordwell p. 133
8. Aitken p. 82

{{Infobox building | name = Haus des Rundfunks | native_name = | former_names = | alternate_names = | image = Berlin - Haus des Rundfunks.jpg | alt = | caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = [[New Objectivity (architecture)|New Objectivity]] | structural_system = | cost = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = Westend | address = Masurenallee 8-14,
14057 Berlin | location_town = Berlin | location_country = Germany | coordinates = | start_date = 1929 | completion_date = 1930 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | diameter = | floor_count = | floor_area = | main_contractor = | architect = [[Hans Poelzig]] | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | awards = | url = | references = }} The '''Haus des Rundfunks''' ("Broadcasting House"), located in the [[Westend (Berlin)|Westend]] district of [[Berlin]], the capital city of [[Germany]], is the world's oldest self-contained broadcasting centre. Designed by [[Hans Poelzig]] in 1929 after he won an architectural competition, the building contains three large centrally located broadcasting spaces, which are shielded from street noise by the surrounding office wings. It is used today by local [[ARD (broadcaster)|ARD]] broadcaster [[Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg]] (RBB) to make programmes carried by its ''Inforadio'', ''Kulturradio'', and ''Radio Berlin 88,8'' channels. The building's large broadcasting spaces are occasionally also used to host concerts. ==History== The building, the ground plan of which is a triangle with two curved sides and a 150-metre-long straight façade clad with ceramic tiles, was constructed between 1929 and 1930 and inaugurated on 22 January 1931 as the seat of the ''[[Reichs-Rundfunk-Gesellschaft]]''. The large, central broadcasting space was finished in 1933. On 22 March 1935 the first regular [[television]] service in Germany ''[[Fernsehsender Paul Nipkow]]'' was begun here, but moved to a separate building on nearby Theodor-Heuss-Platz in 1937. The Haus des Rundfunks also had an important influence on the development of [[stereophonic sound]] and its adoption by radio broadcasting. Some radio programming continued during the war, notably the ''[[Wunschkonzert]] für die Wehrmacht'' ("Request Concert for the Armed Forces"), broadcast from the Haus des Rundfunks on Sunday afternoons from 1939 to 1941. After [[World War II]], the Haus des Rundfunks became something of a [[Cold War]] issue: although situated in the British Sector of [[West Berlin]], it was used by the [[Berliner Rundfunk]] radio station, which was controlled by the [[Soviet occupation zone|Soviet occupation]] forces, until the station moved to [[East Berlin]] in 1952. The building was not handed over to the West Berlin mayor [[Otto Suhr]] by the Soviet military command until 5 July 1956. After considerable renovation work, it was used from the end of 1957 as the home of [[Sender Freies Berlin]]s, which was to merge on 1 May 2003 merged with [[Rundfunk Berlin-Brandenburg]]. ==The building== The Haus des Rundfunks was one of the first buildings in Europe dedicated solely to broadcasting and is exceeded in age only by the [[Münchner Funkhaus]]. It is thus especially noteworthy that the building still offers ideal conditions for broadcast production today. At the time, Hans Poelzig had almost no examples to emulate but he developed ideas which are still valid today: the office and editorial rooms are located in the outer areas of the building, thereby surrounding the three large studio complexes. The largest broadcasting space is the heart of the building, and as well as this there is also a smaller broadcasting room and an area which, with its diversity of acoustic characteristics, is used for the production of [[radio drama]]. Poelzig put a great deal of thought into the acoustic properties of the studios. The chairs in the large broadcasting space were specially designed so that seats had the same sound-absorbing qualities whether occupied or not. In the smaller broadcasting room a hundred wall panels could be flipped. One side of the panels absorbed sound, the other reflected it. In this way very different reverberation effects could be achieved. ==External links== {{Commons category|Haus des Rundfunks}} *[http://www.goethe.de/ins/us/lp/wis/med/en4422034.htm Haus des Rundfunks Broadcasting House, Berlin], [[Goethe-Institut]], Washington, D.C. *{{de icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110719074253/http://besuchertour.rbb-online.de/haus-des-rundfunks/flash/ Haus des Rundfunks], rbb-online.de *{{de icon}} [http://www.berlin.de/ba-charlottenburg-wilmersdorf/bezirk/kultur/haus_des_rundfunks.html Haus des Rundfunks], berlin.de {{coord|52|30|30|N|13|16|33|E|region:DE-BE_type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haus Des Rundfunks}} [[Category:ARD]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1930]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf]] [[Category:Hans Poelzig buildings]] [[Category:Media in Berlin]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Germany]] [[Category:Radio in Germany]]

{{About|the Chinese entertainment and media conglomerate|the South Korean subsidiary|Huayi Brothers (South Korean company)}} {{Infobox company |name = Huayi Brothers Media Corporation
华谊兄弟传媒集团 |logo = Huayi Brothers Media.jpg |logo_size = 200px |caption = Huayi Brothers Media logo |type = Public ([[Shenzhen Stock Exchange|SZSE]]:300027) |genre = |fate = |predecessor = |successor = |foundation = 1994 |founder = [[Wang Zhongjun]], Wang Zhonglei |defunct = |location_city = [[Beijing]] |location_country = [[China]] |locations = 1 |key_people = [[Wang Zhongjun]] (Chairman & [[CEO]]), Wang Zhonglei (President) |area_served = China |industry = {{nowrap|[[Entertainment]]}} |products = Movies, television shows, music, movie theaters |services = Talent representation for musicians and actors/actresses |revenue = {{Increase}} CNY 892,000,000 (2011) |operating_income = |net_income = |aum = |assets = |equity = |owner = Wang Zhongjun, Wang Zhonglei |num_employees = |parent = |divisions = |subsid = Huayi Brothers Film Investment Co., Ltd.
Huayi Brothers TV Service Co., Ltd.
Huayi Brothers Contemporary Culture Broker Co., Ltd.
Huayi Brothers Music Co., Ltd.
Huayi Brothers Advertising Co., Ltd.
Huayi Brothers International Distribution Ltd
[[Huayi Brothers Korea|Huayi Brothers Korea Co., Ltd.]] |homepage = {{URL|http://www.huayimedia.com/}} |footnotes = }} {{Infobox record label | name = Huayi Brothers | image = | founded = 1994 | defunct = | founder = [[Wang Zhongjun]], Wang Zhonglei | distributor = | genre = [[Mandopop]] | country = [[China]] | location = [[Beijing]], [[China]] | url = {{URL|http://ent.sina.com.cn/huayi}} | image_bg = }} '''Huayi Brothers Media Corp.''' ({{zh|s=华谊兄弟传媒股份有限公司|p=Huáyì Xiōngdì Chuánméi Gǔfèn Yǒuxiàn Gōngsī}}) is a Chinese multinational entertainment company that owns a [[film studio]], a television [[production company]], a [[talent agency]], a [[record label]], and a [[movie theater|movie theater chain]] founded in [[Beijing]] by brothers [[Wang Zhongjun]] and Wang Zhonglei in 1994. The company made world news on October 30, 2009 when the Shenzhen Stock Exchange [[ChiNext]] Board was halted, after HBMC's stock price reached 122.74 percent above its IPO price, to open at 63.66 yuan per share.{{cite web | title = All stocks trigger suspensions on China's Nasdaq-style board under price-rise rules on first day | url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90778/90859/6799005.html | accessdate = 12 June 2014}} Patrick Frater of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called it "China’s largest private sector film conglomerate".{{cite web |url= https://variety.com/2015/film/asia/huayi-brothers-michael-uslan-pact-for-thunder-agents-franchise-1201615725/|title= China’s Huayi Brothers Sets Superhero Franchise Pact With Michael Uslan|author= Patrick Frater|date= October 12, 2015|accessdate= October 14, 2015|work= [[variety.com]]}} In 2014, the company was the seventh-largest film distributor in China, with 2.26% of the market.{{cite web |url= http://english.entgroup.cn/uploads/reports/China%20Film%20Industry%20Report%202014-2015%EF%BC%88in%20brief%EF%BC%89.pdf|title= China Film Industry Report 2014-2015 (In Brief)|accessdate= October 15, 2015|work= english.entgroup.cn|publisher= EntGroup Inc}} ==History== The company was founded in 1994 as a film production company. It underwent a comprehensive expansion into the media industry through investing and now produces movies, TV shows, & music and operates a film studio, TV production company, a talent agency, a record label, and movie theaters.[http://www.trmusic.com.cn/intro/about.htm www.trmusic.com.cn/intro/about.htm] In February 2011, Huayi Brothers revealed their plans to create the largest TV and film studio complex in East Asia.{{cite web | url = http://asiapacificarts.usc.edu/article@apa?huayi_brothers_to_build_east_asias_largest_film_and_tv_studio_complex_16432.aspx | title = Huayi Brothers to build East Asia's largest film and TV studio complex | publisher = Asia Pacific Arts | date = 2011-02-24}} Also, they announced that they aim to earn 10 billion yuan in the box office by 2016.{{cite web | url = http://asiapacificarts.usc.edu/article@apa?huayi_brothers_unveils_their_moneymaking_plan_16522.aspx | title = Huayi Brothers unveils their moneymaking plan | publisher = Asia Pacific Arts | date = 2011-03-16}} As of April 2015, the company was worth US$7.9 billion.{{cite web |url= https://variety.com/2015/biz/asia/chinese-media-stocks-stage-major-rally-in-us-and-asian-markets-1201469237/|title= Chinese Media Stocks Stage Major Rally in U.S. and Asian Markets|author= Patrick Frater|date= April 9, 2015|accessdate= April 14, 2015|work=[[variety.com]]}} In 2014 the company announced that it had agreed to invest as much as $150 million in Studio 8, the production company launched by former [[Warner Bros.]] executive Jeff Robinov, but the partnership never materialized. Shanghai-based conglomerate [[Fosun International]] later signed a deal to invest in Robinov's company instead.Verrier, Richard [http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-china-broken-deals-20150906-story.html For Hollywood, the road to China is littered with broken deals] ''Los Angeles Times''. September 7, 2015 The same year the company acquired 79% stake https://technology.ihs.com/511196/huayi-brothers-to-acquire-leading-stake-in-gdc-technologyhttps://variety.com/2014/biz/asia/chinas-huayi-to-pay-125-million-for-d-cinema-group-gdc-technology-1201307397/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/chinas-huayi-brothers-buys-controlling-733146http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2014-09/17/content_18614620.htm in GDC Technology Limited, a ''[[Digital cinema|Digital Cinema]]'' solutions provider, which was held by private equity funds ''[[The Carlyle Group|Carlyle Group]]'' and Yunfeng Capital.https://www.carlyle.com/our-business/portfolio-of-investments/gdc-technology-limitedhttps://www.carlyle.com/media-room/news-release-archive/carlyle-led-consortium-acquires-80-stake-gdc-technologyhttps://www.reuters.com/article/carlyle-cinema-idUKL3E7LH0CC20111017?type=companyNews ==Artists== {{colbegin}} *[[Angelababy]] *[[Feng Shaofeng]] *[[Pace Wu]] *[[Li Xia (actor)|Li Xia]] *Liu Jinshan *Yu Zhen *[[Jia Nailiang]] *[[He Zhuoyan]] *[[Zhao Liying]] ( left in 2010) *[[Jeffrey Tung]] *[[Zheng Ruibin]] *[[Fei (singer)]] (joined in 2018) {{colend}} ==Productions== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox film | name = Illicit Dreams | image = Illicitdreams1994poster.jpg | image_size = | caption = Film poster | director = [[Andrew Stevens]]{{cite web |url=https://letterboxd.com/film/illicit-dreams/|title=Illicit Dreams 1994 Directed by Andrew Stevens|accessdate=2017-07-03 |publisher=letterboxd.com}} | producer = [[Ashok Amritraj]] | writer = Karen Kelly | runtime = 93 min. | released = {{start date|1994|11|02|df=y}} | starring = Andrew Stevens
[[Shannon Tweed]]
[[Joe Cortese]]
[[Michelle Johnson (actress)|Michelle Johnson]]
[[Brad Blaisdell]]
[[Stella Stevens]]
[[Rochelle Swanson]]
[[Dave Carlton]]
[[Jennifer Bassey]]{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Illicit-Dreams-Innocent-DVD/dp/B0002N9YDY|title=Illicit Dreams (Innocent Dreams) [DVD] |accessdate=2017-07-03 |publisher=amazon.co.uk}} | language = English | cinematography = [[Christian Sebaldt]] | editing = [[Terry J. Chiappe]] | music = [[Claude Gaudette]] | country = United States }} '''''Illicit Dreams''''' is a 1994 American [[erotic thriller]] film directed by [[Andrew Stevens]] and produced by [[Ashok Amritraj]]. with music composed by [[Claude Gaudette]]. The film stars [[Andrew Stevens]], [[Shannon Tweed]] (reuniting the two from ''[[Night Eyes 2]]'' and ''[[Night Eyes 3|3]]'') and also stars [[Joe Cortese]], [[Michelle Johnson (actress)|Michelle Johnson]] and [[Brad Blaisdell]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/movies/illicit-dreams/130671/|title=Illicit|accessdate=2017-07-03 |publisher=tvguide.com}} ==Plot synopsis== Dr. Daniel Davis is married to Moira, both of whom have a rocky relationship; Dan has seduced several women who are his patients while treating his wife carelessly. Moira frequently dreams of visiting a large house and makes love to a man named Nick. One day, Moira sees a house that resembles the one in her dream and, to her surprise, Nick is waiting inside. Moira and Nick soon start a love affair. Daniel finds out about it, gets jealous, intervenes, and so Nick sets out to protect Moira from him. ==Cast== * [[Andrew Stevens]] as Nick Richardson{{cite web |url=http://www.ebay.com/itm/Illicit-Dreams-The-Secretary-VHS-Shannon-Tweed-Promo-Screener-w-Booklet-/131747818397|title=Illicit Dreams & The Secretary VHS – Shannon Tweed – Promo Screener w/ Booklet|accessdate=2017-07-03 |publisher=ebay.com}} * [[Shannon Tweed]] as Moira Davis * [[Joe Cortese]] as Daniel Davis * [[Michelle Johnson (actress)|Michelle Johnson]] as Melinda Ryan{{cite web |url=https://www.cineplex.com/Movie/illicit-dreams|title=IIllicit Dreams movie details|accessdate=2017-07-03 |publisher=cineplex.com}} * [[Brad Blaisdell]] as Reed * [[Stella Stevens]] as Cicily * [[Rochelle Swanson]] as Beverly Keen * Dave Carlton as Investigaton{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywood.com/movies/illicit-dreams-59183051/credits/|title=Illicit Dreams1994|accessdate=2017-07-03 |publisher=hollywood.com}} * [[Jennifer Bassey]] as Real Estate Woman == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDB title|0110108}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes |illicit_dreams}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Illicit Dreams}} [[Category:1994 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American thriller films]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] {{1990s-thriller-film-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Interview | image = Interview 2007.jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Steve Buscemi]] | producer = Gijs van de Westelaken
Bruce Weiss | writer = [[Steve Buscemi]]
David Schechter | narrator = | starring = [[Steve Buscemi]]
[[Sienna Miller]]
[[Danny Schechter]]
[[James Franco]] (voice) | music = [[Evan Lurie]] | cinematography = Thomas Kist | editing = Kate Williams | distributor = [[Sony Pictures Classics]] | released = July 13, 2007 | runtime = 86 min. | country = United States | language = English | budget = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Interview''''' is a remake of Dutch film maker [[Theo van Gogh (film director)|Theo van Gogh]]'s 2003 [[Interview (2003 film)|movie of the same name]]. The American version, which premiered in 2007, stars [[Steve Buscemi]] as Pierre Peders (originally played by [[Pierre Bokma]]), a fading political journalist interviewing a [[soap opera]] star, Katya, played by [[Sienna Miller]] (originally played by [[Katja Schuurman]]). This film also features [[Tara Elders]] as Maggie, Molly Griffith as a waitress, and Philippe Vonlanthen as an autograph seeker. Steve Buscemi is also a director of this American adaptation. [[Katja Schuurman]], the actress who played Sienna Miller's part in the original movie, has a small cameo as a woman leaving a limo towards the end of the movie. == Plot == Pierre Peders (Buscemi) is a tough political correspondent infuriated by his editor's insistence he cover a tabloid-level story about the [[paparazzi]] favorite Katya (Miller). Pierre's chagrin increases given the news of a searing [[White House]] [[scandal]] that is just breaking; instead of covering the piece, Peders must visit a posh [[Manhattan]] restaurant and interview Katya, whom he instantly detests. The one-on-one is more of a disaster than either could have predicted, but by some strange twist of fate, Pierre is injured and brought back to Katya's [[loft]]. Once there, [[liquor]] is downed, [[cocaine]] is consumed, minor violence erupts, and the two begin to "dance a [[pas de deux]]" — attempting, not so subtly, to outmaneuver one another psychologically, as dark secrets and long-hidden vulnerabilities emerge. Katya teases Peders into kissing her, which Peders passionately does, but as her cell phone rings and reality reasserts itself, Katya demands that he stop. Peders is exasperated and complains that she doesn't let him finish what she starts, unlike the male [[prostitute]] he once visited. During another of Katya's phone calls, Peders uses Katya's [[laptop]] and opens a folder containing what he believes is Katya's [[diary]]. He is able to barely conceal his surprise when Katya eyes him suspiciously, by saying he is merely [[Googling]] her, as per an earlier suggestion by her. When Katya's attention returns to her phone call, Peders e-mails a particularly expressive and emotional diary passage to himself. Later, unable to forget what he had read, Peders betrays his snooping by asking Katya what has made her lose hope. After an emotional outburst about her loss of privacy, she admits that she has [[cancer]]. At this, Peders is immediately contrite about the way he has been treating her. He learns that no one knows about Katya's illness; she feels that saying it aloud will make it more "real". Peders promises not to reveal the truth about her health; Katya demands that Peders reveal something about himself in return. As Katya films the confession with a [[camcorder]], Peders admits that, as a reporter, he has made up stories and sources, and that he essentially caused his [[alcoholic]] former wife's death. (He took his time responding to her distress call to him - by the time he arrived, she was already dead.) Katya swaps out the camcorder tape when Peders is unaware, and a while later, Peders attempts to do the same. On a clandestine phone call to his editor, Peders - against his promise to Katya - tells him that Katya has cancer. Peders leaves Katya's loft, and as he is walking outside, she calls him on his cell phone. Katya reveals that not only did she lie about having cancer, (the diary Peders believed was hers was actually the diary of the character she played) but she has Peders' confessional tape. She inquires whether she should send it to his editor first or the police. Peders smugly retorts that he swapped the tape first; Katya disagrees and says he only has her rehearsal tape. The movie ends with Peders and Katya watching their tapes - Peders wearing a sullen expression. Katya sips a glass of [[wine]] while watching Peders' confessional tape, but it is unknown if she will follow through with her threat. == References == {{Unreferenced|date=May 2010}} {{Reflist}} == External links == {{refbegin}} * [http://www.interviewthefilm.com ''Interview''] Official website *{{IMDb title|0480269|Interview}} *{{Amg movie|381507|Interview}} *{{rotten-tomatoes|id=10007916_interview|title=Interview}} {{refend}} {{Steve Buscemi}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Steve Buscemi]] [[Category:Sony Pictures Classics films]] [[Category:Films shot in New York (state)]] [[Category:American remakes of foreign films]] [[Category:Two-handers]]

{{Infobox comics organization |image=WhizComicsNo29.jpg |imagesize= |caption=[[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]] and his three Lieutenant Marvels (left to right: Lt. Hill Marvel, Lt. Fat Marvel, and Lt. Tall Marvel) on the cover of ''[[Whiz Comics]]'' #29 (April 1942).
Art by [[C. C. Beck]]. |name=Lieutenants Marvel |publisher=[[Fawcett Comics]] (1941-1953)
[[DC Comics]] (1972-1985) |debut=''[[Whiz Comics]]'' #21 (1941) |creators=[[C. C. Beck]]
(writer unknown) |base=[[Fawcett City]]
Rock of Eternity |members=Lt. Tall Marvel ("Tall" Billy Batson)
Lt. Fat Marvel ("Fat" Billy Batson)
Lt. Hill Marvel ("Hill" Billy Batson) |subcat=DC Comics |hero=y |villain= }} The '''Lieutenant Marvels''' are [[fictional character]]s, a team of [[superhero]]es in the [[Fawcett Comics]] and [[DC Comics]] universes. They first appeared in ''[[Whiz Comics]]'' #21 in 1941. The physical appearance of the three characters was based on three real-life members of the Fawcett Comics staff: Paul Peck (Tall Billy), Ed Hamilton (Hill Billy), and Frank Taggart (Fat Billy).C.C. Beck, "The Human Qualities of the Captain Marvel Characters" in Fawcett Companion, ed. P.C. Hamerlinck (Raleigh, NC: TwoMorrows Publishing, 2001), 28-29. ==Publication history== The Lieutenants appeared periodically in the adventures of Captain Marvel and the [[Marvel Family]] through the early 1950s, and also when the characters were revived by [[DC Comics]] in the 1970s under the title ''Shazam!'', although rarely. They were [[retcon]]ned out of existence during the ''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'' in 1985. Some people, such as Jonathan Woodward in his ''Annotated Crisis on Infinite Earths'' website, suggest that the Lieutenant Marvels died in the last battle of the ''Crisis on Infinite Earths'',Woodwards, Jonathan (2001). "Issue #12, March '86: "Final Crisis". ''The Annotated Crisis on Infinite Earths''. Retrieved from http://www.prismnet.com/~woodward/chroma/crisis12.html on October 27, 2006. although ''[[Who's Who in the DC Universe]]'' claims they survived but lost their powers. The characters were reintroduced in ''[[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Trials of Shazam!]]'' #2 (2006), only to lose their powers in the same issue. They also appeared as inhabitants of [[Earth-5]] in [[Grant Morrison]]'s ''[[The Multiversity]]'' miniseries in 2015. ==Fictional team history== [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]] has its own Billy Batson, and he travels to the W.H.I.Z. radio station with two other Billy Batsons, one from the [[Western United States]] and one from the [[Southern United States]], to visit [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|the "real" Billy]]. To prevent confusion, the western Billy suggests he be called "Tall" Billy, the southern Billy is renamed "Hill" Billy and Brooklyn's Billy is given the title "Fat" Billy. At the "real" Billy's suggestion, all four Billys form the Billy Batson Club. Billy reveals he is Captain Marvel to them, and says they should only say "Shazam!" when he gives them a wink. The nefarious [[Dr. Sivana]] hatches a plan to kill the "real" Billy Batson and sends his three henchmen to find out where Billy lives. Sivana's goons mistakenly find the other Billy Batsons instead and capture them. The mysterious Captain Death captures Tall Billy, Nazi Agent Herr Geyer captures Fat Billy, and bandit "Biggy" Brix captures Hill Billy. Sivana uses them as bait to trap the real Billy after hearing he is their friend, having Brix deliver a note, and demanding he comes to the Mill as Billy. When this happens he is knocked out and captured. Sivana and his henchmen gag Billy and tie him and the other Billys to a log heading towards a buzzsaw, then leave. Billy is able to remove his gag on the buzzsaw, but his shout of "Shazam" can not be heard over the roar of the buzzsaw. With seconds to spare, Billy enlists the aid of his club members and they all shout "Shazam!" together. When the smoke clears, Captain Marvel sees that the other Billys have transformed as well, into Tall Marvel, Hill Marvel, and Fat Marvel. Hill Marvel remarks that they have each changed into Captain Marvel but Fat Marvel counters that by saying that there is only one Captain Marvel. Tall Marvel suggests that they are really [[Lieutenant]] Marvels, hence the trio's name. The Captain and his three Lieutenants easily defeat Sivana and his henchmen, knocking their plane down and apparently killing all the villains except Sivana. After shouting "Shazam!" and transforming back into their civilian identities, the three Billys head back home. The Lieutenants returned from time to time during the Fawcett Comics era to aid their hero. In ''[[Captain Marvel Adventures]]'' #4 they are again kidnapped by Sivana's henchmen. Captain Marvel follows the kidnappers to Sivana's base. The three Billys are tied up under three sharp pendulums. However Billy transforms with them and they defeat the henchmen. They hear a noise in a shed, and find Sivana's daughter Beautia bound and gagged inside. They release her and she reveals Sivana did this. They fly away before Sivana detonates tons of dynamite under the house, then defeat him. They were probably put in suspended animation until 1973, along with many Marvel characters, by the Sivanas. They make their first DC appearance in ''[[Shazam!]]'' #30, when the whole Marvel Family is called upon to destroy Sivana's steel menagarie, which is threatening to wreck [[Pittsburgh]]. The Lieutenant Marvels exist, without powers though still helping the Marvel Family to fight crime, on Earth-5, as seen in ''[[The Multiversity]]'' miniseries by writer [[Grant Morrison]]. ==Powers and abilities== By shouting "Shazam!", the three Billy Batsons are transformed into the Lieutenant Marvels. In this form, they each have the powers of Captain Marvel: the wisdom of [[Solomon]], the strength of [[Hercules]], the stamina of [[Atlas (mythology)|Atlas]], the power of [[Zeus]], the courage of [[Achilles]], and the speed of [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]]. Since they have to share the power, they are each only one-third as powerful as Captain Marvel. ==In other media== In the [[direct-to-video]] [[animated film]] ''[[Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths]]'', three superpowered henchmen with powers similar to the Marvels are employed by [[Superwoman#In other media|Superwoman]], a criminal, [[parallel universe (fiction)|parallel universe]] incarnation of Wonder Woman,http://forums.comicbookresources.com/showthread.php?t=308181&page=2 and referred to as her Lieutenants. However, instead of the "classic" Lieutenant Marvels, the trio appear as criminal counterparts of Captain Marvel, [[Captain Marvel Jr.]], and [[Uncle Marvel]] (listed in the film's credits as, respectively, "Captain Super", "Captain Super Jr.", and "Uncle Super"). In the TV series ''[[Young Justice (TV series)|Young Justice]]'', [[Mary Marvel|Mary Batson]] and [[Captain Marvel Jr.|Freddy Freeman]] as Lieutenant Marvel and Sergeant Marvel joined the team during the five year jump but did not appear in the second season leaving the characters' fate unknown.http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/youngjustice/backstage/interview12.php ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070814192034/http://www.marvelfamily.com/WhosWho/ The Lieutenant Marvels at Marvel Family website] *[https://archive.is/20121209230134/http://www.dcindexes.com/indexes/indexes.php?character=1151 Earth-S Marvel Family Index] *[http://www.captainmarvelculture.com/7lieutenant.html The Lieutenant Marvels at Captain Marvel Culture website] {{Shazam}} {{GoldenAge}} [[Category:Characters created by C. C. Beck]] [[Category:Comic book sidekicks]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1941]] [[Category:Comics spin-offs]] [[Category:DC Comics superhero teams]] [[Category:Marvel Family]]

{{Infobox person | image = Mallory Lewis and Lamb Chop.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Lewis with [[Lamb Chop (puppet)|Lamb Chop]] at [[Kadena Air Base]] in 2004 | birthname = Mallory Hurwitz Tarcher | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|June 19, 1963}} | birth_place = [[New York City|New York, New York]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = Mally Lewis
Mally Tarcher | occupation = Writer, TV Producer, Puppeteer, Creator | years_active = 1991–present | spouse = Brad Hood | children = James Abraham Tarcher Hood | website =mallorylewisandlambchop.com }} '''Mallory Hurwitz Lewis''' (née '''Tarcher'''; changed her name legally in honor of her mother, [[Shari Lewis]]; born June 19, 1963) is an American [[writer]], [[television producer]], [[ventriloquist]] and [[puppeteer]]. [[Lamb Chop (puppet)|Lamb Chop]] is a "[[sock puppet]]" of the mother and daughter.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/lifestyle/2007/09/29/2007-09-29_shari_lewis_daughter_gives_babies_a_hand.html|title=Shari Lewis' daughter gives babies a hand with ABC's|author=Lisa Chase|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|accessdate=22 May 2010 | date=29 September 2007}} ==Early life== Mallory Lewis was born '''Mallory Hurwitz Tarcher''' in [[New York City]]. She is the daughter of [[Jeremy Tarcher (screenwriter)|Jeremy Tarcher]] and [[Shari Lewis]], creator of Lamb Chop.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/TV/9808/03/shari.lewis.obit/|title=CNN - 'Lamb Chop' creator Shari Lewis dead at 64 - August 2, 1998|date=August 3, 1998|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=22 May 2010}} Growing up, Lewis used to sleep with Lamb Chop.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20066121,00.html|title=Master Puppeteer Shari Lewis & Publisher Jeremy Tarcher: It's Not a Match Between Dummies|date=February 2, 1976|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=22 May 2010}} ==Career== Tarcher worked closely with her mother as producer of ''[[Lamb Chop's Play-Along]]''. Jeremy Tarcher had also been part of Shari Lewis's show on [[PBS]]. After her mother's death in 1998,{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/sep/20/news/wk-kidsa20|title=Like mom, she's in the family business - Los Angeles Times|author=Lynne Heffley|date=September 20, 2007|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=22 May 2010}} on the advice of family friend the late [[Dom DeLuise]], Tarcher decided that Lamb Chop should live on for her many [[fan (aficionado)|fans]] and has begun performing with Lamb Chop. It was during this time that she changed her surname to her mother's, of Lewis as an homage. While Lamb Chop may be described as "sassy", "please" and "thank you" are part of the [[Repertory|repertoire]]. Lewis has the same hand size as her mother.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=266&dat=20010601&id=UBYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iW0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4078,6152254|title=Lamb Chop Is Now In The Capable Hands Of Mallory Lewis|date=June 1, 2001|work=[[Google News]]|publisher=[[Kentucky New Era]]|accessdate=22 May 2010}} Lewis said of her decision to take up the puppet: "My mom was one of the world's greatest entertainers. I don't want to challenge that. I don't think it's wise to go there. But I do want to do everything that I can do for Lamb Chop. I'll help keep her going". Lewis had never attempted to imitate Lamb Chop's voice but upon receiving a [[Posthumous recognition|posthumous award]] for Shari, Lewis performed with the puppet, discovering that she had her mother's ability to affect the voice without [[Ventriloquism|lip movement]].{{cite web|url=http://www.talkingcomedy.com/SI-Vent-2005/tv-siVENT05/SL-TV-siVENT05.html|title=SHARI LEWIS: Shari Had a Little Lamb…And Turned a Simple Sock Into a Superstar|author=J.C. Johnson|year=2005|work=TalkingComedy.com|accessdate=22 May 2010}} Lewis is also a writer of children's books, some of which star [[Zoey & Me (book series)|Zoey]], a baby [[orangutan]] character she also puppeteers. Lewis performs extensively for military support organizations such as the [[United Service Organizations|USO]] and the [[Fisher House Foundation]], performing arts centers, and at state fairs around the country. In 2002, Lewis helped raise $275,000 for [[UCLA]]'s [[Brain cancer|Neuro-Oncology]] Program.{{cite journal|pmc=1550327|title=Art of the Brain UCLA Neuro-Oncology Program|author=Judi Kaufman|year=2002|work=Neoplasia Press Inc.|publisher=[[NIH]]|pages=181–183|volume=4|issue=2|doi=10.1038/sj.neo.7900228}} as well as being a founder of Jump For The Cause a women's world record skydiving organization that has raised nearly 2mil for Breast Cancer Research. Lewis is also on the board of the Blue Ribbon. Lewis was the co-host of the 2014 AMG Heritage Awards with host [[Billy Gilman]] and [[David L Cook]]. During the broadcast she accepted the Sandy Hosey Lifetime Achievement Award presented by the [[Artists Music Guild]].{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Mallory|title=Lewis Co-Hosts the 2014 AMG Heritage Awards|url=http://www.americantowns.com/nc/monroe/news/2014-amg-heritage-awards-program-21144723|publisher=American Towns News Organization|accessdate=8 January 2015}} Prior to her death, Shari Lewis sold the rights of Lamb Chop to DreamWorks, though Mallory still owns the live performing rights to Lamb Chop.{{cite web|last1=Cordova|first1=Randy|title=Shari Lewis' daughter keeps Lamb Chop alive, in Mesa 1/5|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/events/2015/12/30/shari-lewis-mallory-lewis-lamb-chop-puppet-mesa/77986316/|website=azcentral}} Lewis hopes to one day put Lamb Chop back on TV.{{cite web|last1=Bucksbaum|first1=Sydney|title=The return of Lamb Chop, and the woman who brought her back|url=http://oychicago.com/article.aspx?id=7886&blogid=132|website=Oy!Chicago|publisher=Jewish United Fund of Metropolitan Chicago|accessdate=8 May 2018|date=November 2, 2010}} ==Awards== Mallory Lewis has won an [[Emmy Award]] for ''Outstanding Writing in a Children's Series'' and has been nominated several times.{{cite web|url=http://www.kidsfirst.org/about-us/Board_Staff_Bios_MalloryLewis.html|title=Who is Mallory Lewis?|year=2010|work=kidsfirst.org|accessdate=22 May 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.americanchronicle.com/articles/view/47873|title=HELP UNLOCK YOUR CHILD'S IMAGINATION!|date=January 3, 2008|work=American Chronicle|accessdate=22 May 2010}} ==Quotes== {{cquote|''It's not the same thing as brothers and sisters, but it's all she got.''}} - Shari Lewis, on 12-year-old Mallory Lewis' relationship to Lamb Chop. {{cquote|''It’s essentially indistinguishable.''}} - Jeremy Tarcher, on Mallory Lewis performing Lamb Chop's voice for the first time. {{cquote|''But then when my mom died, I could. I just let it go and she lives!''}} - Mallory Lewis, on hearing Lamb Chop's voice again. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * [http://www.MalloryLewisandlambchop.com Mallory Lewis and Lamb Chop] Retrieved 2010-05-22. == External links == * {{IMDb name|850350}} * [https://www.myspace.com/mallylewis Mallory's page on MySpace] {{DEFAULTSORT:Lewis, Mallory}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American entertainers]] [[Category:Daytime Emmy Award winners]] [[Category:American children's writers]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:American puppeteers]] [[Category:Ventriloquists]]

revision.comment: clean up, replaced: Cambridge, Mass. → Cambridge, Massachusetts using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Gavotte from French suite n. 5.jpg|thumb|250px|This music manuscript was written by Johann Sebastian Bach and contains the ''Gavotte'' from his ''French Suite No. 5'' (BWV 816).]]
'''Music manuscripts''' are [[handwriting|handwritten]] sources of [[music]]. Generally speaking, they can be written on [[paper]] or [[parchment]]. If the manuscript contains the [[composer]]'s handwriting it is called an [[autograph]]. Music manuscripts can contain [[musical notation]] as well as texts and images. There exists a wide variety of types from sketches and fragments, to compositional [[sheet music|scores]] and presentation copies of [[music composition|musical works]].
==Earliest music manuscripts== The earliest written sources of Western European music can be found in medieval manuscripts of the late 9th century that contain liturgical texts.<ref>Willi Apel, ''The Notation of Polyphonic Music'', 5th ed. (Cambridge, Massachusetts: Medieval Academy of America, 1961).{{page needed|date=August 2014}}</ref> Above these texts small symbols ([[neume]]s) indicated the shape of the melodic lines. Only a few manuscripts survive from that time. New systems were devised over the centuries.<ref>Geoffrey Chew and Richard Rastall, " Mensural notation from 1500" (Notation, §III, History of Western Notation, 4), ''New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', rev. ed., 2001.</ref>
==Preparation of manuscripts and copying of music== In the distant past, each composer was required to draw their own [[staff (music)|staff]] lines (staves) onto blank paper. Eventually, staff paper was manufactured pre-printed with staves as a labor-saving technique. The composer could then compose music directly onto the lines in pencil or ink.
In the 20th century, music staff paper was often printed onto [[vellum]] or [[onionskin]]: a durable, semi-transparent paper which made it easier for the composer to correct mistakes and revise his work, and also enabled copies of the manuscript to be reproduced through the [[ozalid |ozalid process]]. Also at this time, a music copyist was often employed to hand-copy individual parts (for each musician) from a composer's musical score. Neatness, speed, and accuracy were desirable traits of a skilled copyist.
With the advent of the personal computer in the late 1980s and beyond, music manuscript is becoming a lost art, as all of the "drawing" of each note, symbol, staff, written instruction, etc., can now be accomplished by a [[Computer graphics|graphics]] computer software made for this purpose, such as [[Dorico]], [[Finale (software)|Finale]] or [[Sibelius (software)|Sibelius]]. Even individual parts of an [[orchestration|orchestral]] score can be extracted and printed with this method. [[MIDI composition|MIDI]] software is also available, which enables the composer to play notes, melodies, chords, etc. on a [[piano]]-type keyboard and have the result transcribed into manuscript format.{{clarify|date=August 2014|reason=What is "manuscript format"? What does a computer have to do with a handwritten source of music?}}
==See also== *[[Manuscript]] *[[Music engraving]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cpdl.org Choral Public Domain Library] Free downloadable sheet choral music * [http://imslp.org/ Petrucci Music Library] Free downloadable sheet music and scans of early editions * [http://www.rism.info/ Répertoire International des Sources Musicales], free online database to search for current locations of thousands of music manuscripts from around the world
{{Music manuscripts}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Music Manuscript}} [[Category:Musical terminology]] [[Category:Music sources]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox university | name = | image_name = NSD logo 2017.gif | image_size = | image_alt = Stylized image of a mask surrounded by flames | caption = | motto = | mottoeng = | location = [[New Delhi]], [[India]] | established = 1959 | type = [[Public university|Public]] | affiliation = | president = | principal = | chairman = [[Ratan Thiyam]] (August 2013-present) | director = [[Waman Kendre]] (August 2013 -present) | head_label = | head = | faculty = | staff = | students = | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | city = [[Bahawalpur House]], [[New Delhi]] | state = | country = [[India]] | coor = | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | affiliations = [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]] | website = {{URL|https://www.nsd.gov.in}} | footnotes = }} '''National School of Drama''' (or '''NSD''') is a theatre training institute situated at [[New Delhi]], [[India]]. It is an autonomous organization under [[Ministry of Culture (India)|Ministry of Culture]], [[Government of India]]. It was set up in 1959 by the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]], and became an independent school in 1975.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=qYfH1tOwsHcC&pg=PA676&dq=%22national+school+of+drama%22&lr=&as_brr=0 Training - National School of Drama]''The Columbia encyclopedia of modern drama'', by Gabrielle H. Cody, Evert Sprinchorn. Columbia University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-231-14422-9}}. ''Page 766''.</ref> In 2005 it was granted [[deemed university]] status, but in 2011 it was revoked on the institute's request.
==''History''== The origins of the school can be traced back to a seminar in 1954, where the idea of a Central institution for theatre was mooted, subsequently, a draft scheme was prepared in 1955, and the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]], which had [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] as its president, started drawing plans for the institution. Meanwhile, elsewhere in Delhi, Bharatiya Natya Sangh (BNS) with assistance from [[UNESCO]], independently established the 'Asian Theatre Institute' (ATI) on 20 January 1958, and in July 1958, ATI was taken over by the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]] (SNA), India’s National Academy of Music, dance and drama of [[Government of India]].<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2009/20090315/spectrum/main1.htm National School of Drama ..over the past 50 years] [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]] 15 March 2009.</ref><ref name=ns/>
In the following year, the government merged it with the newly founded school, and thus NSD was established in April 1959 under the auspices of [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]]. Initially, the school was situated at [[Nizamuddin West]] and was called 'National School of Drama and Asian Theatre Institute, whose first batch passed out in 1961. During his tenure as the director of the institution, [[Ebrahim Alkazi]] (1962–1977), not just overhauled the syllabus, but also had the students dig and build platforms for a theatre in the backyard of a rented [[Kailash Colony]] house, where NSD had moved.<ref name=hin>{{cite news |title=Theatre is revelation (Interview) |url=http://www.hindu.com/mag/2008/02/24/stories/2008022450160500.htm |publisher=''[[The Hindu]]'' |date=24 February 2008 }}</ref> Later when it moved to its present location, he also designed two theatres for NSD, including a 200-seat studio theatre, and the open-air Meghdoot theatre, under a banyan tree.<ref name=ns/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=COkXM9n7KUcC&pg=PA168&dq=%22National+School+of+Drama%22#PPA168,M1 National School of Drama] ''The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Asia/Pacific'', by Don Rubin. Published by Taylor & Francis, 2001. {{ISBN|0-415-26087-6}}. Page 168.</ref>
In 1975 it became an [[Autonomous entity|autonomous]] organization, under the erstwhile Ministry of Education and Ministry of Culture, Department of Culture, with the name 'National School of Drama' and relocated in May 1975, to its present premises at [[Bahawalpur House]], the residence of [[Bahawalpur (princely state)|Bahawalpur]] a former [[princely state]]. However, the place is generally known by adjacent (now demolished) [[Mandi House]], the former residence of Raja of erstwhile [[Mandi State|Mandi princely state]].<ref name=ns/> In 1999, the School organized its first National Theatre Festival, 'Bharat Rang Mahotsav', generally held during the second week of January each year.
In 2008, the institution celebrated its golden jubilee at its annual theatre festival, ''[[Bharat Rang Mahotsav]]'', with a gathering of its alumni from all over the country,<ref>[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Features/Culture_Cauldron/National_School_of_Drama_celebrates_golden_jubilee_in_style/rssarticleshow/2694072.cms National School of Drama celebrates golden jubilee in style] [[The Economic Times]], 12 January 2008.</ref> the festival’s satellite edition in Mumbai showcased plays of NSD graduates, including Ratan Thiyam’s Prologue, Bansi Kaul (Aranyadhipati Tantiya), Neelam Mansingh Chowdhury (The Suit), Sanjay Upadhyay (Harsingar), [[Baharul Islam (actor)|Baharul Islam]] (Akash), Mohan Maharishi (Dear Bapu) and [[M K Raina]] (Stay Yet Awhile).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/the-graduates/255144/|title=The Graduates|date=28 December 2007|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=2 April 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004221012/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/the-graduates/255144/|archivedate=4 October 2012|df=}}</ref> Waman Kendre was appointed as Director the school in 2013. He will serve a five-year term.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Government Appoints Prof. Waman Kendre as Director of National School of Drama | publisher = Press Information Bureau, Government of India | date = 1 August 2013 | url = http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=97520 | accessdate = 1 August 2013 }}</ref> He has done post-graduate with research in folk theatre of [[Kerala]] from NSD. He belongs to the nomadic Vanjara tribal community of [[Marathwada]] and was one of the leading lights of the Dalit theatre movement in [[Maharashtra]] in the late 1970s.<ref>{{cite news | title = Marathi theatre veteran to head NSD | newspaper = The Telegraph | date = 26 July 2013 | url = http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130726/jsp/nation/story_17159090.jsp#.Ufo9lBcW0Yo | accessdate = 1 August 2013}}</ref>
===Deemed university status=== On 16 March 2005, the Government of India granted the NSD the status of [[deemed university]].<ref>[http://pib.nic.in/release/rel_print_page1.asp?relid=7814 National School of Drama gets Deemed University Status][[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)|Ministry of Human Resource Development]] 16 March 2005."The Government has declared the National School of Drama, New Delhi as Deemed to be University with immediate effect."</ref><ref>[http://www.deccanherald.com/deccanherald/mar162005/update11.asp ''NSD declared deemed university''] [[Deccan Herald]] 16 March 2005.</ref> However, in 2010 the NSD Society asked for the deemed university status to be revoked since "[it] could undermine the professional training, autonomy, and flexibility required in the creative fields such as theatre." Thus, in October 2011 the status was revoked on request of NSD.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article2518525.ece |title=The Hindu : News / National : NSD loses deemed varsity status on own request |work=thehindu.com |accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref>
==Performing Wings==
===Repertory Company=== [[File:NSD at Anugoonj 2011.png|right|250px|thumb|Play by the NSD at the Anugoonj, 2011 (cultural festival of the [[GGSIPU]], Delhi)]]
The professional performing wing of NSD, the 'National School of Drama' Repertory Company was set up in 1964, with an aim to promote professional theatre in India. It first head was [[Om Shivpuri]], followed by [[Manohar Singh]], [[Ram Gopal Bajaj]] (Acting Chief), J.N. Kaushal (Acting Chief), Anuradha Kapur (Acting Chief), and Suresh Sharma, Sagar Kamble, Atul Singhai (Animation chief).
Today, the Repertory Company, has staged over 120 plays based on the works of about 70 playwrights and featuring around 50 directors in several countries, and various cities across the nation, and has its own festival every year, called Annual Repertory Company Summer Festival, in which it perform new and past plays.In 2004, the repertory celebrated its 40th anniversary with a theatre festival in New Delhi.
===Sanskaar Rang Toli=== In 1989 NSD established the ‘Theatre-in-Education Company’ (T.I.E), called 'Sanskaar Rang Toli', today it has become India's premier educational resource centres, and coaches children aged 8 to 16 years. The company regularly performs plays for school and adults audiences alike, and has its own yearly theatre festivals, 'Jashn-e-Bachpan' and Bal Sangam.<ref>[http://www.nsd.gov.in/nsd_tietours.htm T.I.E.]</ref>
==Performing spaces== The schools has three auditoria within the campus:
* Abhimanch Auditorium *Sammukh Auditorium * Bahumukh Auditorium
Apart from that it has a studio theatre and minor performances spaces used on special occasions, like the Bharat Rangmahotsav.
==Regional Centres==
In a bid to decentralize its activities, NSD opened Regional Resource Centres (RRC) across India, the first of which was opened at [[Bangalore]] in 1994.<ref name=ns>[http://www.nsd.gov.in/Annual_Report_2005-06.pdf NSD Genesis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718213711/http://www.nsd.gov.in/Annual_Report_2005-06.pdf |date=2011-07-18 }} NSD website</ref> A new centre was established in [[Varanasi]].
==Bharat Rang Mahotsav== {{Main|Bharat Rang Mahotsav}} [[Bharat Rang Mahotsav]], or the 'National Theatre Festival', established in 1999, is the annual [[theatre festival]] of National School of Drama (NSD), held in [[New Delhi]], today it is acknowledged as the largest theatre festival of [[Asia]], dedicated solely to theatre.<ref name=bh>{{cite news |title=11th Bharat Rang Mahotsav to begin from Jan 7 |url= http://www.financialexpress.com/news/11th-bharat-rang-mahotsav-to-begin-from-jan-7/406807/|publisher=[[The Financial Express (India)|Financial Express]] |date=5 January 2009 }}</ref>
==Notable alumni== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Ashutosh Rana]] * [[Adil Hussain]] * [[Amal Allana]] * [[Anupam Kher]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/anupam-kher-my-ups-and-downs-have-taught-me-about-life/articleshow/64320596.cms|title=Anupam Kher: My ups and downs have taught me about life - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> * [[Anuradha Kapur]] * [[Annu Kapoor]] * [[Atul Kulkarni]] * [[B. Jayashree]] * [[B.M. Shah]] * [[B.V. Karanth]] * [[Bansi Kaul]], * [[Bhanu Bharti]] * [[Devendra Raj Ankur]] * [[Dolly Ahluwalia]] * [[Govind Namdev]] * [[Irrfan Khan]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/magazine/2017/nov/04/i-would-never-leave-bollywood-as-my-base-irrfan-khan-1690528.html|title=I would never leave Bollywood as my Base: Irrfan Khan|work=The New Indian Express|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> * [[M.K. Raina]], [[Bansi Kaul]] * [[Madhu (actor)|Madhu]] * [[Manohar Singh]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.asianage.com/life/art/120917/himachal-keeps-theatre-alive-with-amateur-dramatic-club.html|title=Himachal keeps theatre alive with amateur dramatic club|date=2017-09-12|work=http://www.asianage.com/|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> * [[Manushi Chhillar]] * [[Mohan Maharishi]] * [[Mohammed Zeeshan Ayyub]] * [[Mukesh Tiwari]] * [[Nadira Babbar]] * [[Naseeruddin Shah]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/acting-is-learnt-not-taught-naseeruddin-shah/story-hgeNXfx1mImjj4OhM3a3ZN.html|title=Acting is learnt, not taught: Naseeruddin Shah|date=2018-03-16|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref> * [[Nawazuddin Siddiqui]] * [[Om Puri]] * [[Omkesh Khotkar]] * [[Pankaj Kapur]] * [[Pankaj Tripathi]] * [[Piyush Mishra]] * [[Prasanna]] * [[Rajesh Sharma (actor)|Rajesh Sharma]] * [[Ram Gopal Bajaj]] * [[Rajpal Yadav]] * [[Ratan Thiyam]] * [[Ratna Pathak Shah]] * [[Rita Ganguly]] * [[Robin Das,]] * [[Rohini Hattangadi]] * [[Sai Paranjpye]] * [[Santanu Bose]] * [[Sanjay Mishra (actor)]] * [[Satish Kaushik]] * [[Seema Biswas]] * [[Shanta Gandhi]] * [[Subrat Dutta]]: ''[[Bibar]]'' * [[Surekha Sikri]] * [[Suresh Bhardwaj]] * [[Swanand Kirkire]] * [[Tannishtha Chatterjee]]: ''[[Bibar]]'' * [[Tigmanshu Dhulia]] * [[Uttara Baokar]] * [[Virendra Saxena]] * [[Yashpal Sharma (actor)]]
{{div col end|3}}
==Directors of NSD== {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; font-size: 85%; background:#ffffcc; color:black; width:20em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" ! style="background-color:#cccccc;" | Chairpersons of NSD |- | style="text-align: left;" | * [[K.P.S. Menon]] – 1976-Feb.1978 * [[Kamaladevi Chattopadhyay]] - March-Nov.1978 * [[L. M. Singhvi]] – Nov. 1978-82 * [[Shanta Gandhi]] – 1982-84 * Suresh Awasthi – 1984-86 * [[Vijaya Mehta|Vijaya F. Mehta]] – 1988-92 * P.C. Joshi – 1992-96 * [[Chandrashekhara Kambara]] – 1996-Nov.2000 * [[Amal Allana]] – May 2005 – present<ref>[http://www.nsd.gov.in/nsd_pchairperson.htm NSD chairperson] NSD website.</ref> |} NSD has had ten directors since its establishment in 1959:<ref>[http://www.nsd.gov.in/nsd_pdirectors.htm Previous Directors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227081550/http://nsd.gov.in/nsd_pdirectors.htm |date=2007-12-27 }} National School of Drama, Official website.</ref> * Satu Sen (1959–61) * [[Ebrahim Alkazi]] (1962–77) * [[B. V. Karanth]] (1977–82) * [[B. M. Shah]] (1982–84) * [[Mohan Maharishi]] (1984–86) * [[Ratan Thiyam]] (1987–88) * Kirti Jain (1988–95) * [[Ram Gopal Bajaj]] (1995-Sept.2001) * [[Devendra Raj Ankur]] (2001-3 July 2007) * [[Anuradha Kapur]] (July 2007- July 2013) * [[Waman Kendre]] (August 2013 onwards)
== Molestation allegation == In August 2018 a woman student alleged molestation<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/news/india/national-school-of-drama-student-alleges-molestation-by-guest-teacher-1834097.html|title=National School of Drama Student Alleges Molestation by Guest Teacher|work=News18|access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref> that she was inappropriately touched by National School of Drama's guest professor Suresh Shetty during the entrance workshop.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/delhi/girl-alleges-molestation-by-national-school-of-drama-professor-during-test-5292115/|title=Girl alleges molestation by National School of Drama professor during test|date=2018-08-05|work=The Indian Express|access-date=2018-08-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/applicant-says-65-year-old-nsd-teacher-molested-her-during-test/articleshow/65274777.cms|title=Applicant says 65-year-old NSD teacher molested her during test - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref> The accused, professor was a retired Academics Dean of NSD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/woman-who-alleged-molestation-not-our-student-national-school-of-drama-1895606|title=Woman Who Alleged Molestation Not Our Student: National School Of Drama|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-08-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/national-school-of-drama-student-alleges-molestation-by-guest-teacher/story-a17UXBCu0y5o8DXbXyxNSJ.html|title=National School of Drama student alleges molestation by guest teacher|date=2018-08-04|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-08-05|language=en}}</ref>
